column4: Does anyone use a TTS application to have the computer read text??? I don't know how to open Ocra, I tried installing Ksayit and KTTSmgr, but none of them seem to work. Does anyone have experince with Text-to-Speech?
the only decent TTS engine there is around is Festival, i bet all those applications you've tried need it installed. what language do you need it for?
hey again, I need it in english, KTTS was aking me to locate Festival, but I didn't know where to point it and /usr/bin/festival dd not work
ok, start by doing « echo "This is a test." | festival --tts » to see if festival itself works
BRB, downloading it
you'll also need a voice besides the "festival" package itself. get festvox-kallpc16k for male american english
what are the other voices I can install and do i gut apt-get install them?

yes, of course, both festival and the voices can be obtained with apt-get or Synaptic. do an « apt-cache search festival » to list all the voices, or « apt-cache search festival english » for just the english ones
- I installed the voices, not I get "Linux: can't open /dev/dsp" when i echo text and pipe it through festival
uhm, are you on KDE?
no just plain ubuntu (gnome)
oh, i thought you were on KDE given you tried kttsd etc... i don't know, i'm on KDE myself, it's possible that /dev/dsp is blocked by the GNOME sound daemon i guess
i tried kttsd because it was the only choice i was given
what are you looking for exactly? a screen reader, or just a wait to read text files aloud...?
I'm looking for TTS - I have KSayIt to work, but theres a lot of echo in the voice
echo? that's weird... Festival's voices certainly aren't top quality (not comparable to most commercial TTS, no), but *echo* is kind of weird
any idea how I can use AT&T voices or other voices?
not really, i don't think they're supported by festival, i really think you'd have to resort to commercial third-party solutions
I swiched the audio from aRts to ALSA, that took away the echo

other TTS frontends / screen readers specifically for GNOME aside from "gnome-orca" are "lsr" and "gnopernicus", in case you want to give those a try. the audio quality will still depends on festival though
I do, but I have no idea how to open orca...
cannot help you must since i don't have GNOME... if it's not in the menu, you can always try « dpkg -L gnome-orca | grep bin » to see what the main executable program is
